column4: which of these repositories you use is very much up to you and your preferences.

i understand and i know that. by default i can see that they are checked (at other software) Indipendent and Indipendent (source code)? why Canonical Partners, Canonical Partners (source code) aren't checked by default and what do they provide me if i will check them. will they provide me something important?
canonical, the company behind ubuntu, has some contracts with other companies which make proprietary software. the results of these contracts are available in this repository.
it includes one variant of adobe flash player and reader, i think.
thank you for clarification. so do i have to check them, am i loosing something important if i leave them uncheck (default) or should i check them?
i couldn't tell what's important to you
ok. i c. i leave them uncheck as default.
(as an example) here's a list of packages in the partner repository for 12.10 x86_64: http://archive.canonical.com/ubuntu/dists/quantal/partner/binary-amd64/
you can also browse the directory structure of the extras ("independent") repositories this way.

i realized that ubuntu center installed a 2nd Canonical Partners (other software) source and it was checked. Can i safely remove this duplicate source and leave the default which was created by the system's installation and leave it unchecked as default?
if there are duplicates usinng the same repository location then you can remove one, yes
removing them using update manager's option is it a total remove or do i have to remove manually anything more?
that's sufficient
ok thanks a lot.
as long as they still show in update manager they remain in /etc/apt/sources.list* but they will be commented out and thus inactive.
the dupicate i deleted already they dont be shown in update manager. are they still in /etc/apt/sources.list* as duplicates?
if it fdoesn't show greyed out in update managed then it's all fone
*gone
no they doesnt show at all. must they have gone. the same procedure must be followed for every othe remove of a software source. isn't it?
if you really want to delete any notion of an apt source, for whatever reason, yes. but normally just disabling them is fine, and allows you to reenable them later.
!ops tdlguik1c
yes i know that and i am following already this method. it is very convenient.
